p.rs:
; obtaining by false pretences from
Frederick Roberton the sum of £30, with intent to defraud;

obtaining by false pretences from
Albert James Smith the sum of £150, with intent to defraud.

div1.p: Mr. W. A. Metcalfe prosecuted. Mr. Penry Oliver defended.

FREDERICK ROBERTON , 29, Cannon Road, Plaistow, caterer. In July, 1906, I advertised in the "Daily Chronicle" for a situation as manager of a dining-room. Prisoner called on me and said he wanted a manager, he was opening up new premises, and that he had several good going businesses in the provinces and in London. He showed me the lease of 25, White Rock, Hastings, which he said he was going to open as tea and refreshment-rooms and boarding house, and proposed that I should undertake the management for 50 per cent of the profits. He showed me proposed agreement (produced), and at my request altered the deposit from £50 to £30, which I paid him by cheque. He said I was not to take my household furniture down as he had a lot ready to go down, and the working utensils would he sent down, that he had spent £120 on the place, and that the furniture had all been paid for. I believed all that or I should not have parted with my £30. I went down the next day, July 24, with my wife and children and remained on the premises till September 15, 1906. We opened on August 5 (Bank Holiday), and did a fair trade. Prisoner called about three times and took what little cash I had. I told him I had paid the bills out, and he said, "Could not you 1st the trades
people wait?" I said I did not do business like that, I had paid them, and gave him the balance, which amounted to about £12. I lived on the premises. Up to that time I did not know debts were owing by the Business. About a week alter I arrived bills came in for the working utensils, which I paid out of the takings. Plummer, Roddis, and Co., sent in a claim for instalments on the furniture on the hire purchase System, which I did not pay, and they put a man in possession. I wrote to prisoner at the address he had given me—Sinclair Gardens—and had the letter returned through the post. I have had no part of my £30 returned, which were my savings. I had to send to London to borrow money to get back.

Cross-examined. I prepared and wrote the agreement. I knew it was to be a new business. I went down and saw the place was being fitted up as dining rooms. Prisoner said the business should be worked up, and if sold I should hart half-share of what it fetched—that was put in the agreement. The business started well. We took £31 in the first eight days, and it showed a fair profit throughout, the receipts for the lowest week being £10. The gross profit is usually 75 per cent. I took in all £111. I paid all bills for butcher's meat. Prisoner did not pay for any. He told me to engage a large

staff and not to study the profits the first month. None of the money I paid him was for goods supplied to the business. There was no mention of any furniture on the hire system, or I should not have parted with my money. He told me the furniture and utensils were all paid for. Nothing was said about paying the rent out of the takings. All the outgoings were to be paid out of the takings. My brother-in-law came down. I never told prisoner he would buy the business for £100—such a suggestion is untrue.
Re-examined. The takings were £111, out of which I paid £93 and gave prisoner £12. Nothing was said about paying the rent. I knew by the lease he showed me it was £180 a year without rates and taxes.

CAMPBELL MCINTYRE , secretary to Lockhart's, Limited. My com
pany are owners of 25, White Rock, Hastings, of which we granted lease to prisoner at £180 a year for three years from July 24, 1906. We took possession, as we have received no rent.

HARRY THOMAS MOORE , managing clerk to Plummer, Roddis, and Co., Limited, house furnishers. On Tuesday, July 24, 1906, prisoner called and said he wanted about £40 worth furniture for opening a cafe in White Rock on the hire-purchase system. We gave him particulars. He called and selected furniture amounting to £41 7s., and gave references to Keen, 43, New Oxford Street, and to the general manager of the London and North-Western Railway. He gave the name of Walter Waller. He said he had two or three other cafe's, including The Creamery, Windsor. He paid £6 deposit. On July 30 the furniture was sent in to 25, White Rock. On August 27 the first payment was due, and, not being paid on August 30, we put a man in possession. We sent a telegram to the address given as that of the prisoner, which was returned.

ROBERT HENRY PATTENDEN , manager, Bruce and Co., house decora
ters and shop fitters, Hastings. On July 27 I received a telephonic message, and to see prisoner at 25, White Rock. He said he desired some internal repairs done promptly, which we did to the amount of £20 5s. 6d. We received no payment.

JAMES CHAMPKIN , owner of 12, Sinclair Gardens, Kensington. In March, 1906, prisoner took over an agreement of those premises at £75 a year for three years. The previous tenant paid the first quar
ter's rent. The premises were vacated in July, and I have taken possession, and re-let them. I received no notice from the prisoner that he was giving them up, nor did he return the key. I found them empty, and flooded with water.

ELLEN TOOLEY , 55, Huntingdon Street, Barnsbury, widow. On July 6, 1907, I replied to an advertisement in "The Daily Chronicle" for a manageress of a coffee and dining rooms. On July 23 a man not the prisoner called, and took me to 207, Westminster Bridht Road, where the workmen were fitting up premises. I then saw the prisoner at Gray's Inn Road. He said he had rented the place, and he wanted me to take the management, and to pay £40 deposit At my request he agreed to take £30, which I paid. We signed
agreement produced. He told me he was a caterer. I told him I had the furniture for my own rooms. I was there about two months and left. I received £5 back from prisoner.

Cross-examined. I found the business was too much for me, and he suggested I should take charge of a boarding-house. I left because I found everything so unpleasant. A woman came in, and super
seded me.

ALFRED JAMES SMITH , 38, Dunster Gardens, Brondesbury. In July I was introduced to prisoner at 207, Westminster Bridge Road. He ssid he had a business there, and also one in Mile End Road, and he wished me to advance a sum of £150. He said 207, Westminster Bridge Road was doing a very good business, that there was no debt owing upon any of the businesses, he wished me to take charge of the Westminster business, supervise it, and also to control the three different branches—Westminster, St. John Street, and Mile End, that I was to reside on the premises, and he would have every accommodation made for me. I advanced the £150, and have had none of it back. (To the Judge.) He did not tell me there was another manageress in the place. If I had known, that, I certainly should not have parted with my money. I did not see Mrs. Tooley until at the police-court—he did not tell me she had paid him £30. I believe he had these prosperous businesses.

Cross-examined. I met him on August 11, about the date the business opened. He showed me the three businesses, and he after
wards purchased a business in Moorfields. He took me to see it, and I said I thought it would cell for £100. He told me be had been offered £80 for the St. John Street business. I told him I thought that was the best of the lot. I paid him £150 down on August 21. He did first suggest that I should advance £75. I signed an agree
ment that I was to have an equal share of the three business, to reside at 207, Westminster Bridge Road, and to have my £150 returned to me in full on a month's notice. Ten days after I saw it, the Westminster business was opened I made no suggestion to take it ever. His son suggested that I should take over the lease and goodwill of 207, Westminster Bridge Road, but the matter was then in my solicitor's hands, to whom I referred him. I have never had any of my money back.

CECIL CULVERHOUSE , of Messrs. Cluttons, agents of the Ecclesiasti
cal Commissioners. On September 3, 1907, we granted to the prisoner three years agreement for 207, Westminster Bridge Road, it £120 a year. We have received no rent. The premises are vacant—we have not taken possession.

Cross-examined. The rent is payable is advance, but it is condi
tional on certain repairs being done. There is about £3 worth of work to be done. Prisoner has expended money on the premises.

Detective-sergeant
WEILLIAM EUSTACE , K Division. On October 20, at 6.30 p.m., I saw prisoner at 207, Westminster Bridge Road. I said, "I am police officer and hold a warrant for your arrest." I read the warrant; he made no reply. When charged he made no

reply. On November 5 I made a further charge against him in reference to the £30 and £150. He made no reply. I found amongst his documents those which had been read to-day. I have been since to 207, Westminster Bridge Road—the premises are closed.

ERNEST KNIGHT (prisoner, on oath). I called to see Roberton in answer to his advertisement. I have been a caterer for the last 20 years and have been in the habit of buying or starting coffee and tea businesses for resale. As a rule, I have found them shut up, and have opened and sold them. In July, 1906, I took the Creamery at Windsor, worked it up, and sold it; then took 25, White Rock, Hastings. I knew the premises well and that there was a good op
portunity for a dining and refreshment rooms, as they were opposite the bandstand. I took them for a friend of mine, who disappointed me. I said to prosecutor, "Do you think you could manage a first
class place?" He said he and his wife could. I told him I was only taking the place to resell it, that if he went as manager he was to have a half-share of all the profit and of the sale price. They had been used as dining rooms and had been shut up for six months. He went to look at them, and agreed to be manager under the agreement read. I suggested to him that as he was only going down to work the place up and sell it it would not be worth while moving his fur
niture, and that two rooms should be furnished on the hire system, the hire being paid out of the profits. The place was opened. The first month I was at Hastings nearly all the time, but I gave him to understand he would hare to take entire charge, that he was to look on it as his business. I sent in the first week's stuff. The first night he took about £7 and said, "Do you want any of this money?" I said, "No, keep it and pay the bills." On the Saturday he said, "We have taken £31—do you want any money?" I said, "Give me £2 of it to pay for what I have sent in," which he did. Alto
gether I received about £12. According to the takings, I ought to have had about £30 or £40. I had sent in the first week's butcher's meat and several other things. I had a half-share interest in Sinclair Gardens as a boarding house from Christmas, 1906. The rent to March was paid out of money due to me. The furniture was re
moved without my knowledge and in my absence in August by my partner. The landlord took forcible possession of the premises be
fore any further rent was due. I received £30 from Mrs. Tooley. I told her I was buying a place in Westminster Bridge Road; she was taken to see the premises, and consented to go there and went in. The first Sunday we were rather busy and she said she thought it would be too much for her; there were three in the kitchen, and she said she could not get on with the girl. She did not give me formal notice till the next Saturday. I then suggested she should take the management of a place I was negotiating for in Endsleigh Gardens, which she agreed to do. The business fell through and she then told me she was going to live with her sister and store her furniture. She moved out at seven a.m., before I got there, and saw me at 10 a.m. and asked if I could give her the money back. I said it was

not convenient, but would give her £5, which I did, that I was nego
tiating to sell the St. John Street business, and as soon as I got rid of it the should have the remainder of her money. She seemed quite satisfied, and said she did not want to press me—that the wiaa going to live with her sister. I was offered £60 for St. John Street, but Smith advised me not to take £60—it was worth £100. Smith was introduced to me at Westminster Bridge Road. The first suggestion was for him to put £75 into that business. I showed him the St. John Street and Mile End Road business, and he then asked me what I would take for a half-share in the three businesses. I suggested £150, which he agreed to. He gave me £5 deposit. John Street was opened the week alter, and Mile End the same week. They were both carried on at a profit. I took him to see the business at Moorfields. The man had had it eight yean, and wanted to go abroad. Smith said, "Certainly, buy it at the price offered—it is worth £100"—which H certainly is. He was entitled to a half-share of everything. I said, "As the businesses are opening out, you can
not expect a lot of profit till they are well stabilished, but if you prefer to have a set sum a profit on your investment, we will make a new agreement, and you shall have £6 a month for the loan of your £150, and 10 per cent, on all moneys the businesses fetch when sold. An agreement was drawn up to that effect and signed. Shortly alter that he had a little disagreement. I said, "I will give you your £150 back and £10 for the Man of it." I had had it a month. He said, "No, you are not entitled to give me notice." Finally, he gave me notice to withdraw.

Cross-examined. Smith would have had the whole of his money beck if I had not been arrested. I told Robertson I should not give him a shilling. I had had his £30, and he had had £100, of which £75 is profit, of which I have only had £12. He only took these proceedings because he knew he could not get what he claims in a civil court. When I got the £30 from Roberton, I had the Creamery at Windsor, of which I had negotiated the sale for £200. It was a prosperous business. I have received £100, but the purchase has not been completed. My other business was Sinclair Gardens. I sup
pose the telegram was sent back because I was not there—they ought to have sent ft on to me at Hastings. I did not say I was carrying on a number of successful businesses in London and the provinces. In April, 1907, I was managing a business in Grays Inn Road for a friend. At Christmas I took she business in Clerkenwell Road, sold it at Easter, and then took charge of Gray's Inn Road without wages. I have not borrowed money on that by representing that as my busi
ness. They did not turn me out. I have bad a lease granted me of 148, St. John Street—it was not refused because my references were unsatisfactory.
(Friday, November 22.)
I did not try to obtain £50 from Astram or Gardiner. As Smith was not going 13 take charge of Westminster Bridge Road, I wanted

another manager. The business was taking £50 a week. Mrs. Tooley agreed to wait till I sold St. John Street. I say these were perfectly bona fide negotiations on my part. I know a man named Salter, an estate agent—he sold a business for me. I witnessed an agreement between Slater and Mrs. Bolter. I told her the business she was taking was in a good position, and, if carried on properly, would be all right. I do not know that Salter and Perry have been convicted in recpect of that matter—I know Salter was not convicted. I heard he was charged. I saw Mrs. Astram and Mrs. Gardiner and Mrs. Osborne with regard to being manageress of 70, Westminster Bridge Road.

Re-examined. I have had an offer for Westminster Bridge Road of £200, and but for being arrested should have sold it. It was a valuable business—£800 was refused for it four years ago. The names mentioned are people who have answered my advertisement. Mrs. Gardiner came with her son and decided to take it, and I was going to the solicitor's to see about the lease. I said the half-quarter's rent in advance, and I was allowed £32 for repairs out of the next £60 rent to Christmas. The work has been done. With regard to White Rock, Hastings, I was allowed two months' rent for repairs, and there would be a month's rent due on September 29. With regard to Sinclair Gardens, I entered into possession in Feb
ruary, taking the liabilities from Christmas. I paid the March rent and the June quarter was paid out of my money. While I was away the furniture was removed without my knowledge or consent, and the landlord took forcible possession when there was no rent due till September. I saw my agents, and we returned the agreement and got a clear acknowledgment for the rent.

Verdict,
Guilty.

Sentence,
15 months' hard labour.
BEFORE MR. JUSTICE RIDLEY.
(Friday, November 22.)

STOWE, Henry (22, labourer),
HAYES, Ernest (25, horsekeeper),
HILL, Thomas (24, labourer)
; all robbery with violence on
Herbert Thomas and stealing from him the sum of 13s.

HERBERT THOMSAS , Chrichton Avenue, East Ham, insurance agent. On the night of October 2 last I was travelling from Aldgate to Upton Park Station by the last train but one. I had in my left trousers pocket £52 in gold, on top of which I placed a tobacco pouch, cigarettes, and matchbox to prevent it from rattling. In my right-hand pocket I had about 13s. or 14s. out of a sovereign I had changed at Aldgate. When I got out of the train I went into the lavatory. The three prisoners then came in behind me. I turned round to walk out, and just as I got outside the lavatory Stowe came to the side of me and put his hand in my right-hand waistcoat pocket

saying, "What have you got for us to-night, governor?" I, knowing the class of men in front of me, was careful what I did. I was look
ing after the £52 and said, "It is no good you touching that, it is only a knife at that end of the chain." I said, "The clock is at the other end." I thought I had better talk to them in their own vernacular. Stowe took the watch out and handed it to Hayes, who looked at it and said, "That is no f—g good, give it to him back, it is not worth a tanner. Don't get pinched for that." While that was going on Hill put his hand in my right-hand trousers pocket and got out what he could. Then, as Hayes handed me back the watch he took out the remainder. We then walked up the platform, because the porter was turning the lights out. As I walked in front I heard one say, "We have made a bloomer to-night it is not in his ski" (pocket). They pushed and hustled me all the way up the staircase. When we got to the top where they take the tickets I stopped and spoke to the ticket collector and explained to him how they took my watch and chain and gave it to me back again. Stowe came up and said, "What is the master, governor? Hasn't he got his ticket? We will pay for him." I said, "Go away and let me go home, you have had enough of it to-night. I went to go oat of the station, the ticket collector went away, and as I went out of the door Stowe and Hayes got hold of me by the arm and pulled me back as I went to get on the motor-bus. Before that Hayes fetched me a blow on the side of the fate. As they pulled me back I felt a prick in my left leg, and I thought it was a knife coming into me. (Trousers produced.) At that time Hill had gone away round the corner. Then the porter came up and I ran for the door again. They went out to wait for me. Then the porter shut the door and shut me in, keeping me there till he got a policeman, who saw me home. I was in a state of col
lapse; they knocked me about so my arm was all bleeding. I iden
tified the prisoners at the police station three weeks afterwards amongst a crowd; my leg has been bleeding since where I was kicked.

Cross-examined by Stowe. In the first instance I did not identify. you because you did not take your cap off before I came in; directly you took your cap off I did identify you. You were dressed differently from what I had known you. When asked at the police court if I saw the ticket collector I had a hazy idea I had spoken about the watch. I cannot tell how you knew I was carrying the money. I know you as hanging about Queen's Road and selling tips, etc. I had heard your character before. I heard that you had been convicted of assaulting the police.

Cross-examined by Hayes. I am an insurance agent for the Union in Cornhill. I am my own employer. I am a public man; I have made speeches which no doubt you have exaggerated. I have not incited people to break windows and things like that. I waited half an hour in the porters' room for the policeman to come.
Cross-examined by Hill. I did not say at the police court that I changed the sovereign at the Aldgate booking office. I said I

changed it at a public-house. I have only known you about Upton Park the last 12 months. I do not know if you have been convicted. I have seen you several times since the affair, but I left it to the detectives to take you in charge.

To Mr. Justice Ridley. I was to pay the £52 the same day; I had £23 for one man and the rest for the solicitor. I had to pay in the money the next day, but I did not do so; I went to the detective and showed him it, and then went to the bank. It was a claim I had to settle; I settled it by cheque instead of cash. It was for a burglary in Barking Road; I sometimes have these large sums in my pockets, but it won't occur again. I will do it by cheque. The prisoners know well I have this insurance business. There are any amount of men I have claims for.

CLAYTON , 164, Third Avenue, Manor Park, railway porter, Upton Park Station. I remember the train coming in on the night of October 2 at 12.35 from Aldgate. After it came in I saw Mr. Thomas and the prisoners. They were at the far end of the platform. I saw the four get out of the train. They did not seem to be in a hurry. I went to put the lights out. They went along, but Thomas going first, and went up the staircase. I saw prisoners hustle him. Then I went into the waiting room nearest to the lavatory to put out the light. Before that I saw the four go into the lavatory. I identify the three prisoners. I went up to the gate, and Mr. Thomas was at the side of it telling the collector about his watch. The three then went out, and Stowe came back again and said, referring to Thomas, "If he has not got his ticket I will pay." Thomas said, "I want nothing to do with you; you have had enough; I am in the hands of pickpockets." I did not hear Stowe say anything then. I went and closed the two further doors at the entrance to the station, and the ticket-collector having finished his duty went away, and I was left there with Stowe and Thomas in the booking-hall. Then Hayes came in, and after hustling him Hayes struck bun a blow, knocking him down, and they also kicked him. Then Thomas made a rush to go out, making an attempt to catch a Union Jack bus that was passing, but he was prevented by Stowe and Hayes. He then turned round and struck them with his umbrella. I rushed out and made a noise like that of a whistle, and they ran away. Mr. Thomas came in and I shut the door and locked it. He was in a state of collapse. I then took him to the porters' room, where he was for about half-an-hour, I should think, while I fetched a policeman, who came and took him home.
Cross-examined by Hayes. I did not identify you at the police-station on Saturday night. When the policeman came I do not know what Thomas said to him. I did not listen.

Cross-examined by Hill. I have seen you and know your name. The reason I did not pick you out at the police-court was because I was not certain. I did not see you do anything to Thomas except hustle him on the platform.

HENRY STANLEY , coffee stall keeper. On October 2 I was at my stall outside Upton Park Station. I saw the three prisoners with Mr. Thomas. I saw Hill come out of the station first of all, a few minutes before the others. Then I saw Thomas come out with Stowe and Hayes, and they were having an argument. Then I saw Thomas try to get away on to a motor bus and Stowe hang on to him and stopped him. While I was serving a customer they got back to the station. Hill remained outside. I started to go to the station and Hill come across. I thought something was the matter. Hill said, "Don't put that b——g flap on my head," so I put it up again and went towards the station, bat I turned round and saw Hill on the counter trying to gat inside, so I came back. Then the other pri
soners came up and stopped talking at the corner of the stall. Stowe was getting on to Hill about not being in the station to help them. Stowe said, "We misted a f—g chance." There was a little con
versation, and they said, "We had better set away from here or we shall hear more of this." Then they went off down Queen's Road. My coffee stall is about 40 yards from the station; I identified the three man.

Cross-examined by Stowe. My stall is in Queen's. Square, by the fountain. I could see anybody coming out of the station from my stall. It is facing the station. You were under the electric light on this occasion, and were quite discernable. Mr. Thomas struck you with his umbrella, in the middle of the road. (Stowe said he hoped witness was not carrying out his threat made in September about having his own back.) Mr. Justice Ridley cautioned prisoner to be careful in making accusations.

Cross-examined by Hayes. When at the police station on Satur
day night I said I do not know your name. I said I knew Hill and Stowe from the first. I do know you well. I have not known you to interfere with me. I did not see you with Thomas, but you came out of the station after this last train and went round the square. You did ask me for a herd-boiled egg.

Detective-sergeant
FREDERICK STEVENS , Plaistow. At 8.30, on Oc
tober 26, I was in Green Street with Detective Edwards and others, and saw the three prisoners. I said, "We are police officers, and we are going to arrest you on suspicion of being concerned together in robbing Mr. Thomas, and assaulting him on the 2nd of this month." Hill said, "What are you going to take me for? I had nothing to do with it." Hayes made no reply. On the way to the station Stowe said, "Highway robbery, governor? That sounds a bit serious." At the station they were placed with other men. Hill and Hayes were identified by the prosecutor. Stowe was identified by the railway porter. They made no replay to the charge. Imme
diately after, while waiting to be put into the cells, Stowe said, "If that man lost 13s. that night we ought to get 10 years' each; if not, directly he steps outside this station he ought to meet with the severest accident that he ever had in his life." Stowe was searched—a knife, and skeleton key and a penny were found on him. On the

way to the court on October 28 Stowe said, "You managed it very neat on Saturday night—you did not give many chances away, but we are innocent. You could not expect us to say we did it if we did, could you?"

Cross-examined by Stowe. I believe the key would open any door in Plaistow. I arrested Hayes at the time in question when the last witness told him the charge. On the way to the station he said, "This is all right; what is it all about?" I said, "You were told. I am taking you to Plaistow Station for being concerned with others for assaulting and robbing Mr. Thomas outside Upton Park Railway Station on the 2nd inst." He said, "I don't know nothing about it."

Police-constable
MERCER (K 87). I arrested Hill at the time in question. When Stevens told him the charge, he said, "I had nothing to do with it. On the way to the station he said, "What did you say it was for?" I replied, "Assault and robbery outside Upton Park Station about three weeks ago." He then said, "I know nothing about it. I suppose we shall get a fair chance." He made no reply to the charge.

ELIZABETH FRANKLIN , 43, May Road, Plaistow. On October 1 last I was living at 111, St. Marys Road, Plaistow, where I occupied one room on the third floor. I went to bed that night between 11 and 11.30. Hill lived there. He did not sleep in my room. Sometimes he would pay me a visit in the night. I heard him come in that hight but did not see him. I think he came in between 1 and 2. He did not came into my room. I was up at 10 in the morning. Stowe came downstairs. He did not live there. I heard Mrs. Hood, who lived in the house, say to him, "Have you got any beer?" He said, "Yes, send the jug up." I took a jug upstairs, where I saw Hill and Hayes. Stowe had gone out into the yard. Hayes lodged with Hill. Hill had been in arrears with his rent, but paid the landlady 8s. that morning, and gave me 2s. He was hard up the day before—in fact the whole three never had nothing—that I can prove. On the morning of October 2 they all went out about 11.
Cross-examined by Stowe. I did not see you come in at night-time. I saw you in the morning about 10.
Cross-examined by Hayes. I never saw you after pension morning at all. I saw you out with Mrs. Hood and Tom. You came home late. I was waiting up for you.
To Mr. Justice Ridley. Pension night is October 1. They were home on pension night. I do not live at 111, St. Mary's Road now.

Cross-examined by Hill. I remember your paying Mrs. Hood 8s., and you called me out of the kitchen to give me 2s. The detective called and asked me if I had been pawning any stolen goods or jewellery. I said, "No."
Cross-examined by Hayes. As far as I know you came in between 1 and 2. I had no clock.
Re-examined. I have been to Brixton Prison to see Hill. I have not talked over anything. It is the truth what I have said. I thought I heard Stowe laugh when he came in on pension night.

ELEANOR HOOD , 43, May Road, Plaistow. I lived at 111, St. Man's Road, Plaistow, on October 1 last. Hill was my lodger. He rented a back room at 2s. a week. Hayes came with Hill. They were joint tenants. They were not at home from 11 to 11.45 on pension might. I had been to sleep and woke up when they came home. I looked at my husband's watch, and it was 2 o'clock; that was half an hour fast. I heard footsteps but no voices. At 10 in the morning Stowe came down to wash. I asked him if he had any beer. He said, "Yes, send up a jug," and Miss Franklin took it up. He paid me up on pension day. The three prisoners went out together on the morning of October 2.
Cross-examined by Stowe. I saw you in the morning between 9 and 10, when you came down to wash.
Cross-examined by Hill. There are other people on that landing, but they were in before you came home.
(Defence.)
MINNIE STOWE (prisoner's wife). Stowe was in bed and asleep at one a.m. on October 1. (To the Judge.) He called it October 2.
Cross-examined. It was a Tuesday. At the police court I did not even know what they were charged with. I learned afterwards. Mrs. Hood and Miss Franklin are strangers to me.

HENRY STOWE (prisoner, on oath). On October 1 I left home about three o'clock. I arrived at the "Queen" public-house in Green Street about 5.30, when I met Hill and Hayes. I stopped in their company till about nine and had several drinks, which we generally do on pension day. I left them about nine or 9.30 and got home a little after 10, when my wife and mother-in-law were sitting there. They passed a remark to me and said I looked a little bit drunk. I said "Yes, I had several, I think I will go to bed," and I did. I went out the next morning and made my way to Hills house. I had arranged with him to have the rent off me, which he was owing at it the time of his arrest. That is all I say. I can safely say when this was supposed to have happened, between one and two on the morning of the 2nd, I was in bed with my wife.
Cross-examined. I have heard what Mr. Thomas said about what occurred at the railway station. It is not true. I heard the coffee stall keeper swear he saw me outside the station. It is not true.
ERNEST HAYES . (prisoner, not on oath). At 10.30 that night I went home and went to bed. Hill came home and found me in bed.

THOMAS HILL (prisoner, not on oath). That is quite true. Stowe left me between nine and 10, and Hayes left me about 10.30. I stopped at the public-house till 11. I thought I would go down to Bromley, which I did, and left Bromley about 11.10. I got a drop of beer in a bottle and came back to Upton Park Station and went to the coffee stall, and asked for a hard boiled egg. I went towards home, and went to my room about 12.45 and see Hayes in bed and said to him,

"Ernie, will you have a drop out of this bottle?" He says, "Yes." The previous morning Stowe saw me about having his back room. My landlady had taken my sheets and things off my bed and pawned them, and as this was pension night I gave her 8s. When I asked if she had got my things out of pawn she said, "No." She had been out drinking and got drunk and spent the money, and I had to lay in bed without sheets and blankets on.

Verdict,
Guilty.

The Jury added a rider in which they said it reflected somewhat discreditably on the railway concerned that it should be possible for one of their passengers to be robbed and violently assaulted on their premises at a station which was apparently protected by only two of their servants.

Mr. Frampton, on behalf of the company, thought the Jury could not have in their minds that the last train was going at that station—a District Railway train, which had no doors to be closed by the porters on the platform side. There was a ticket collector on the stairs and three or four persons were on the platform together, and they went from the platform to the ticket collector. There was no suggestion made to the ticket collector of the robbery, and the real offence took place outside the station and after the prosecutor came back to the station, when he was protected By the porters there. There was no anticipation of a robbery taking place, and if a serious complaint had been made it would had been attended to.
Mr. Justice Ridley. I am not sure that I quite agree with the rider.
Stowe and Hayes confessed to a previous conviction.

Sentences. Stowe and Hayes,
12 months' hard labour.

Hill,
Six months' hard labour.
BEFORE JUDGE LUMLEY SMITH.
(Saturday, November 23.)

WAKER, George (28. labourer), and
SICKELMORE, Herbert (22, labourer)
; both breaking and entering the counting-house of the
Home-Light Oil Company, Limited, and stealing therein two bicycles and other articles, the goods of
Frederick Hardy, and one razor, the goods of
Albert Potter.

Sickelmore
pleaded guilty.
Mr. W. B. Campbell prosecuted.

FREDERICK HARDY , 3, South Church Gardens, East Ham (local manager for the Home-Light Oil Comrany, limited. Stratford). I recognise the two bicycles in Court. They are mine. Prior to my seeing them recently in the possession of the police I last saw them on the evening of October 10 alt five o'clock, when I left the premises. Mr. Potter stopped to lock up. I came to business about eight o'clock in the morning on October 11. The bicycles were not there. I missed other property. The razor was Mr. Potter's. I do not know either of the prisoners.

ALBERT POTTER . I live at 11, Bath Road, Stratford. I am a clerk in the employ of the Home-Light Oil Company. On Thursday, Oc
tober 10, I looked up the premises at 8.20 in the evening; the bicycles were then on the premises. I went the next morning to open the premises. The door was intact, but the box of the look was forced off. I found some things missing; the bicycles were in the superin
tendent's private office.

WILLIAM WOODS . I keep a marine store dealer's shop at Leyton
stone. On October 15 the two bicycles in Court were brought to my place by the prisoner Waker and another man not in custody. Waker asked me to buy the bicycles. I refused. He then asked me if I would lend him something on them. I refused to do that. He then asked if he might leave them there a little while, to which I con
sented. The prisoner and the other man led the bicycles into my shop. Prisoner said he would call for them later on, but he did not do so. The same day two police officers called.

Cross-examined by prisoner Waker. One of the bicycles was not fetched up on the Monday afternoon, and the other one was not fetched up on Tuesday morning. You did not come and say to me, "Are you going to bay the bicycles."

Detective-sergeant
WILLIAM SMITH , Victoria Park. On the even
ing of October 15, together with Police-constable Orchard, I saw the prisoner Sickelmore. I spoke to him and arrested him. He made a statement to me, in consequence of which I went to Woods' shop at Leytonstone and recovered the two bicycles. They were given up to me by Woods. Having got the two bicycles, at 9.20 that evening I went to the "Lord Napier" public-house, Hackney Wick. I saw the prisoner Waker in the bagatelle room. I was with Police-con
stable Orchard. I said to prisoner, "You know me," and he said, "Yes," When I got him outside I said, "I am going to arrest you for being concerned with three others in stealing on the night of the 10th from the Home-Light Oil Company two bicycles." He said, "I don't think." I subsequently conveyed him to the Victoria Park Police Station. Sickelmore was detained, and they were both charged at the West Ham Police Station. In answer to the charge Walker there said, "I admit being at Woods' wife the bicycles, but I never had a finger on them." The next morning at the West Ham Police Court he said, "I only went with the other man to try and sell them."
Cross-examined by Waker. You made that statement at West Ham Police Court.

Police-constable
CHARLES OECHARD , 276. Victoria Park. On Octo
ber 15 I was present when the prisoner Sickelmore was arrested. I went with Detective-sergeant Smith to Woods' marine store shop and the bicycles were hended to me by Woods' foreman.

WILLIAM WOODS , recalled. (To the Judge.) When the prisoner Waker and the other man not in custody came on the Tuesday they both spoke—the other one spoke first and Waker afterwards. Waker took an active part in the conversation with a view to selling the bicycles.
(Defence.)

GEORGE WAKER (prisoner, on oath). I live at 17, Twigger Road, Old Ford. I am a waterside labourer. With regard to being in pos
session of the bicycles, I swear I did not take them to Woods' shop. I did not go to Woods' shop until Tuesday afternoon; the bicycles were already on his premises. I went with this other man. I did not know he was going there about the bicycles until we got to the shop. When we got to the shop he asked me to go and ask Woods if he would buy the bicycles. He must have been up there before me because the bicycles were already there. The name of the other man was "Stanford,' or some name like that. I do not suppose I have been in his company five times.

Cross-examined. I do not know the other man's proper name; I cannot say where he lives. I know a man named Clark; I cannot say where he lives. I was with him on October 10 for about 10 minutes. I was on my way home then. I do not know this shop belonging to the Home-Light Oil Company. I was with Sickelmore, Clark, and Stanford about 10 minutes on the night of October 10. I know that Stanford pleaded guilty here to breaking into these pre
mises. I do not know what Stanford is; he looks as if he were in a better position than I am according to his dress. He told me he bought the bicycles three months ago down the Lane. I thought they were two old bicycles. I did not know they were in the condi
tion that they are. I did not see them properly when they were in Woods' shop. I only saw the back wheel of one of them. When I asked him where the bicycles were he said Woods already had them on his premises.
WILLIAM WOODS , recalled. (To the Judge.) The bicycles were brought to my shop on August 15 at three o'clock in the afternoon. I had just returned from dinner. Wakers statement is not true.

Sickelmore (called on behalf of the prisoner). The first bicycle was taken to Woods' shop on the 14th. Stanford and dark stop the bicycles. I was concerned with them; they asked me to come with them, and asked me if I would stand in with them. I could not say who burst the door open; I was outside over the fence. I saw the bicycles handed over the fence by Stanford and Clark. Stanford is a glass blower, I think; I cannot say what has become of him; Clark is a labourer. On the morning of the 14th Stanford said to me he was going to Woods. I saw him take the bicycles in the afternoon to Woods. He took the first bicycle up on Monday afternoon, and then the largest bicycle up on the Tuesday morning. This is what Stanford told me. Waker was with me on the night of the robbery until nine o'clock, and then he left us. He went towards Old Ford; I live at Victoria Park.

Cross-examined. When I was arrested by Detective-sergeant Smith and Police-constable Orchard, I made a statement. I told them where the bicycles were—that they would find them at Woods'. I have not had an opportunity of talking with Waker since the police court proceedings closed, only coming along in the van. (To the Judge.) I heard Police-constable Smith's deposition read over to

him by the clerk of the Court at West Ham Police Court. I saw him sign it as a correct account of what took place. I did not know what to say as it was being read over. This was the first time I had ever been in such a place.

Verdict,
Guilty.

Prisoner confessed to having been convicted of felony at Clerken
well Green on February 9, 1904; and other convictions were proved.

Sentences: Waker,
20 months' hard labour; Sickelmore,
18 months' hard labour.
(Monday, November 25.)

p.rs:
; robbery with violence on
Henry Edward Brown and stealing from him the sum of £2 5s.

div1.p: Mr. Metcalf prosecuted; Mr. Coumbe defended.
(In opening the case for the prosecution Mr. Metcalf stated that the reason why the prisoner had not been charged before was that he could not be found.)

HENRY EDWARD BROWN . I am a seaman. On November 15, 1905, I was lodging at No. 39, Milford Road, Plaistow, which was occupied by a Mr. and Mrs. Read. On that day I had a seaman's advance note, which I cashed for £3 10s. with a man named Smith. Having received the money I went with Mr. and Mrs. Read and Mrs. Smith to a public-house called the "Peacock," near the Custom House. We had a drink there. While we were there two men came into the "Peacock." and got into conservation with me. One of them was the prisoner. The other man has already been convicted. We were there about half-an-hour. I treated them, and gave them is each. After I did that Mr. and Mrs. Read and myself left the public house, and we all got on a tramcar going to Barking Road. When I was on the tramcar I found these two men were on the tramcar at the back of me. I spoke to them and paid their fares—1/2 d. each. Mr. and Mrs. Read and myself got down at Barking Road and went into the "Swan" public-house. We remained there about 20 minutes to half-an-hour. The two men followed me in there. I was talking to them part of the time and also to my friends. I again treated these man to drinks, and gave them another 1s. each. I then left the house with Mr. and Mrs. Read, and we walked towards 39, Milford Road. When we were near the house—it was rather dark—we heard footsteps behind us, and I stopped to see if it was really the same two man that were following me—I had my suspicions that what they had said, namely, that they were shipmates of mine was not quite true. I turned round and saw the other man (Marwell) and the prisoner, and asked them if they were following us. They said no, but they lived close round there, and I said, "Well, that is how you come to know me then, but you have never been shipmates with me." With the permission of my landlord I invited the men into stopper, which we finished shout 10 o'clock. The prisoner then said, "Who is going to start the game?" I did not know whether he meant a game of play or any other game, so I said, "Excuse me, this is not my house. I

only lodge here, and my landlord has to get up very early to go to work; we have enjoyed ourselves very nicely, I think it is time for you to leave." I got up to show them to the door, and going into the passage the prisoner placed himself rather quickly in front of me, and I was between the two men, and just before we got into the passage the prisoner turned round and struck me a violent blow on the nose, which knocked me backwards, and at the same time the other man (who has been convicted) put his left arm across my shoulder, caught me by the throat, bent me backwards, and gave me the "knee" in the back. The result of that was that it broke one rib and, I believe, fractured another. They could not get me on the ground, but they forced me on the stairs. While in that position they tried to tear my right pocket. Finding they could not do that, they tipped the money on the floor. I had £3 or £4, because I had been paid off only the day before, but I had at least £2 5s. They picked the money up, and one of them said, "Run for it," and they ran out of the house. I was taken to the Poplar Hospital the next day by my landlord. I was kept there as an in-patient for a week and afterwards treated as an out-patient. I did not see the pri
soner again until Saturday week in the Stratford Police Court. I was asked to pick out the man who had assaulted and robbed me, and I failed to pick out the prisoner; I picked out another man.

Cross-examined. I cashed my advance note about three o'clock. I had other money with me. I had not met any friends earlier in the day or had drinks with anybody else. We were about half an hour in the "Peacock" public-house. I had two or three drinks at the outside. I only drank common ale. All this time the prisoner and Maxwell were in the public-house. I invited them into the "Swan." I had two or three drinks there. I quite knew what I was doing. I admit I picked out another man and failed to identify the prisoner. I am positive that prisoner was with us. I recognised him at the West Ham Police court. I had a couple of drinks at the "Swan." When in 39, Milford Road I sent for a gallon of ale. I do not think it was all drunk that night. The passage was not light like an electric car, but light came through the back kitchen door. I could see distinctly who hit me; I swear it was the prisoner. I can
not say exactly what time we started supper.
(Wednesday, November 27.)

ALFRED READ , engineer's labourer, 178, Star Lane. In November, 1905, I was living at 29, Milford Road, and had a lodger named Brown, a seaman. On November 15, about four o'clock in the after
noon I went with my wife and Brown to the "Peacock" in Free
mason's Road, Custom House, to change an advance note. We saw Mrs. Smith there While we were there prisoner came in, and Maxwell, who has been convicted. Brown had a conversation with the two men and stood drinks; he took out his money and gave the two men 1s. each. I went with Brown and my wife on a tram down the Barking Road. The two men were also on the tram. Brown and I got off the tram at the "Swan," and went in there.

The two men also got off the tram and Brown invited them in. We were in there about three-quarters of an hour. The two men had some drink which Brown paid for and he gave them another shilling each. After leaving the "Swan" we went to my house in Milford Road, about a quarter of an hour's walk. The two men were behind us in the Whitmore Road, about 100 yards. When we got to my house Brown asked my permission to invite them in and I gave it. They came in to supper. Before supper Brown asked prisoner to get some beer; he went out and got a gallon. Then prisoner went with Brown to the corner shop to get the supper. When they were on the point of leaving prisoner said to Brown, "Who is going to start the game?" The two men and Brown went into the passage and closed the door. I could see what happened. Brown went to shake hands, but prisoner struck him on the nose; then they wrestled with him but could not get him down. I could see from the light in the kitchen. I went to Brown's assistance, and got knocked about. I had a black eye. I could not say whose hand struck me. Besides the scuffle I could hear the jingling of money. The men then went off. My daughter ran to get assistance and I attended to Brown. My daughter is now very ill, and unable to attend here. I found Brown bleeding at the nose. He said he was injured in
ternally. He had to go to the hospital next day, and remained there as an in-patient for a considerable time. He afterwards had to attend the hospital for another seven or eight days.

Cross-examined. I first saw prisoner in, the "Peacock" at about four o'clock. On that day I was not at work. I do not recollct what time we left home on that day. We came out with the prosecutor. We might have had one drink before, we met at the "Peacock." We went to cash the advance note at the "Peacock," and Smith was there. We were there about three-quarters of an hour and had two drinks, or it might have been three. We left there and went to the "Swan." I am quite positive prisoner came into the "Swan." Brown paid the fare of the two men and paid for the drink at the "Pea
cock." I cannot say how long we stopped in the "Swan." It was quite dark when we got home. They lift my house at about a quarter to 10; they had been there about three hours. There is no light in my passage, but when the kitchen door was open there was a full light from the kitchen, and I could see out there. The next time I saw prisoner he was coining out of the van at the Stratford Police Court. There were two other men coming out of the van. I did not see an old man get out. I was standing in the yard outside the Court. Two or three other people were standing there. I will swear that Mrs. Smith was not standing there. Mrs. Smith was nowhere near me until we were ranged to go up the passage way to identify. I can
not say whether she was in the yard. She did not make any communi
cation to me before we went up to identify. I went up and down the line twice before I identified prisoner. I did not notice whether the police officer was walking up and down with me. I did not hear him say anything. When my daughter was brought in to identify

prisoner I was right at the further end; she could not see me but I could see her. I did not hear the police officer say anything to her. I had never seen prisoner before the night on which the offence was committed; I never saw him again till two years afterwards, and I then picked him out at once. I had previously seen him get out of the van.

Re-examined. I had seen prisoner on the afternoon of November 15, 1905. When I went to the police court I was standing in the yard when the van drove up. I saw two or three men get out. I had not been asked before that to see if I could identify any of the men. It was a pure accident that I saw him. I think he was the first who came out of the van. When the men were put up for iden
tification I was about 50 or 100 yards away from Mrs. Smith. I did not speak to her before I identified prisoner. No suggestion was made to me as to the man I should pick out. I was present when my daughter identified the same man.

EMILY ELIZABETH READ , wife of last witness. In November, 1905, I lived at 29, Milford Road. On November 15 I went out with my husband and a lodger (Brown). We were in the "Peacock" between three and four, and remained there about half an hour or an hour, or it might have been longer. While we were in there two men came in. I recognise prisoner as one of them. When we left the "Pea
cock" Brown, my husband and I went on a tram to Barking Road and went into the "Swan" public-house. The two men followed us on the tram and into the "Swan." They had drinks there and an
other shilling was given to them. When we left the "Swan" we went to our own house. The same two men followed us, and Brown invited them to topper. We all had supper together. After supper the two men and Brown went to the door to say "Good-night." I was standing just inside the kitchen and could see what passed in the passage. Maxwell shook hands first and Chasey afterwards. Chasey said, "Who is going to start the game?" Brown said, "We do not want any more game to-night. Finish up to-night—you can call again to-morrow night, if you like." He said he did not know that he meant by saying that. The next I saw was Mr. Brown on the stars and Chasey had him by the throat, the other man was fumbling round Mr. Brown's pockets. I heard the jingling of money. Directly they picked the money up they ran off. I never saw Chasey again till last Saturday week at Stratford Police Court, when I saw him in the dock. He is the same man that I saw at the "Peacock" and at the "Swan," and in my kitchen.

Cross-examined. I was the last witness called at the Stratford Police Court. I never saw prisoner from the time he was in my house until I saw him in the dock at Stratford Police Court. I was not taken out to identify him because my daughter had done so. No attempt was made to show me this man. I identified him directly I got into Court. I had known for two years that somebody had been knocked about in my house. I was told that the man had been caught. Then I was taken to the police court and saw prisoner in the dock and at once said, "That is the man." I was not in

Court when my husband and Mrs. Smith identified him. I heard my husband give evidence. I am quite positive prisoner is the man because he had been in my house two hours. We had been having a sing-song. Chasey went and got a gallon of beer. Before that we had had drinks at the "Peacock," and so on. I might hare had mild and Burton; I did not have gin and bitters.

Mrs.
SMITH , wife of Charles Smith, dock labourer. At half-past three on the afternoon of November 15 Henry Edward Brown came to my house and my husband cashed an advance note and gave him £3 10s. I afterwards went with Brown and Mr. and Mrs. Read to the "Peacock." We remained there about half an hour. I had one drink. I saw two men come in. One of them I knew before. I have no doubt about prisoner being the man. I had never seen the other one. He was the man I gave evidence against at the Old Bailey—Maxwell. I was present been prisoner was put up for iden
tification at Stratford Police Court. I did not speak to Read with a view to pointing out the man. I did not got to the Court till 20 minutes to 11. I know nothing of what happened after they left the "Peacock," I only know Chasey was with them. Mr. Smith gave Brown three gold sovereigns and a half sovereign for his advance note.

Cross-examined. I did not see the prison van gave up. I am quite positive prisoner did not see me and Mr. Read standing in the yard when the van drove up. I have known prisoner for five or six years. I heard that there had been a scuffle at this house the next night after it occurred. I knew that Chasey was with them up to the time they left the "Peacock," and I was told he was one of the men who was in the row. Having known that for two years I was taken to Stratford Police Station and identified Chasey, having known him for five or six years and been with him up to the time he left the "Peacock."

Inspector
BLANTREE , K Division, stationed at West Ham. I was in charge at the West Ham Police Court on the identification of prisoner. He was brought in from one of the cells and placed with nine other men in the passage of the police court. The witnesses, Mr. Read, his daughter and Mrs. Smith were called in one by one, and each iden
tified him. I made no suggestion to any to the witnesses. It was my duty to see that the identification was properly carried out.

Cross-examined. I do not think Mrs. Read was asked to identify prisoner. I was not in charge of the case. I was not present at the police court when Mr. Read identified him. I was standing in the passage when the little girl identified him. She was not taken up and down the line of men: she walked up the line once and back again, then went and touched him. I do not think the detective said, "Do not be frightened" just when she got near prisoner. He might have used those words because the little girl seemed alarmed. I did not hear them. Some of the men in the line might have had hats on. It was a wet morning, and we had difficulty in getting men. Several of them had cloth caps on, and I gave prisoner the option of having hats on or off.

Inspector SIMMONS, K Division, stationed at West Ham. I was not present when Mrs. Read identified the prisoner. I was present when he was put up for identification by the prosecutor, but he did not identify him.
Cross-examined. I think Brown first identified prisoner when he was in the dock.
(Defence.)

JOHN CHASEY (prisoner, on oath). In 1905 I was living with my father and mother at 18, Francis Street, Tidal Basin. Prior to that I had been working with a costermonger selling rabbits. I was not in regular employment. When I was employed I made about 5s. a day. That was not enough to keep me, and I wanted to get away to sea. I had been trying for five or six weeks before this time to get a ship. I went to the shipping offices and went about the docks trying to jump a ship. That means that when a man who has signed on does not turn up you get a chance to take his place. You can get on without signing. If the man who has signed is not there at the time the ship is leaving anyone with a character can go. In moving about in that way I got to know Maxwell, I had not known him before. On this particular day in November, when with Max
well, I met prosecutor. He asked Maxwell to have a drink, end I being his friend went too. We went to the "Peacock," then Brows invited us to go on the tram to the "Swan." When I got on the tram I saw some other man I knew, and I thought I would go with those I knew best. We went to a public-house called the "Abbey Arm's." I had been drinking mild and bitter and old and mild, but there I had whisky. I went outside because they refused to serve me any more; the other men took me home, and I did not know any more till the next morning, when I found myself in bed. I did not go into the "Swan." Maxwell went with Brown and the others. I stopped at the "Peacock" about half an hour or an hour. I think we had four or five drinks. When I got up next morning I went out to look for a ship. When I went home again my mother said, "My son, there has been a detective here for you." I said, "What for?" She ssid, "He wants you; there has been a robbery with violence." I said, "Well, mother, I am not going away for what other people have done." The next day I went to Tilbury. I went from there to New York till the boat got back. Then on January 11 I went away and came back on the same ship in 1907, a 12 months' voyage, and I have been sailing out of Tilbury ever since. I was away one month on the first voyage. Then I was in England 11 days and then went away for a year. I went round Cape Horn to San Francisco. I was there about the time of the earthquake. In consequence of that the ship was delayed, and went on coasting voyages; otherwise the voyage would have been only about eight months. There is no truth in the story that I went to the supper party. It is a conspiracy. There is no truth in the statement that I knocked Brown down and subsequently robbed him. When I was arrested I was taken from Brixton to West Ham Police Court in a

van in my own clothes, all crumpled up. I was the first to gat out of the van. A man named Williams got out with me—a man about 54 years of age. Mrs. Smith, Mr. Read, and his daughter were stand
ing together in the yard. I am positive Mrs. Smith was there. I heard some whispering; between them but could not hear what was said. I then walked into the Court and was afterwards brought out and placed with a number of other men for identification, men between 20 and 40 years of age, one man with a high hat, four or five with hard hats, and one with a cloth cap like myself. I was the only one with a neck handkerchief Mrs. Smith came and identified me, and when I came up to the Court the same man who saw me get out of the van came and identified me. He picked me out, and then stood a little way off while his daughter packed me out. Every time the girl got near me the detective kept saying, "Do not be frightened," and ultimately she picked out me. Afterwards prosecutor was brought up to identify me. I was brought up in a private cab that time. He walked up and touched another man. I said, "You have touched the wrong man."

Cross-examined. I only knew Maxwell as being in the shipping offices. I knew he lived in Newton Street. I will take my oath I was not in the cupboard when he was taken into custody. I may have been in the duck at that time, or I may have been at the shipping offices. I do not know where I was. I admit I was with Brown in the "Peacock." Maxwell and I had drinks with him and he gave us a shilling each. We were on the tram afterwards and got down at the "Swan." Then I left then to go to the "Abbey Arms" with my friends. I cannot say whether any
body else took my place with Maxwell when I left. I swear I was not there after we got off the tram. It was two or three days afterwards I heard the detective had been asking for me. I shipped at Tilbury on the 22nd. The little girl Read picked me out. She had not been in the "Peacock," I was not asked whether I would have all the men with hats on, or off. I say that is a deliberate untruth on the part of the Inspector.

Re-examined. On the day this is alleged to have occurred, I went to look for a ship as usual and the next day as well; when I came home my mother made a statement. Then I went to Tilbury and got a ship on the 22nd.

JOHN CHASEY . I am a stevedore. The prisoner is my son. On November 13, 1905, I met with an accident and broke my arm, and in consequence of that remained at home. My son came home the worse for drink, with two seafaring men, between nine o'clock and half-past. I was in the kitchen having supper. He sat in the arm-chair and had supper with me, then went to bed and remained there. He was brought home intoxicated. I do not know where Brown lives.

Cross-examined. I did not know Maxwell and did not know my son had been about with him. It was not by my advice my son went to Tilbury. He went before the detective called. I knew he was going because he had been previously. My wife might have told the detective that he had gone to Tilbury and was going to sea.
MRS. CHASEY (wife of last witness and mother of prisoner): Prisoner was living with me in November, 1900. About that time my husband had

his arm broken. I think it was on November 13. On November 15 my son was brought home the wore for liquor by two seafaring men. That was about nine o'clock in the evening. He went to bed and remained there till next day. I do not know Milford Road, Plaistow. I should think it would take twenty minutes to go to Plaistow by tram. It is about ten minutes' walk from my house to the tram.

Cross-examined. I saw the detective when he first came and told him my son had gone away the day before. I told him he bad gone to sea. I knew my son bad gone to get a ship. When the detective asked to see my son I said, "You cannot see him, he is not at home, and possibly he has gone to sea, be went out with that intention."

Verdict,
Guilty.
Sergeant Stevens proved previous convictions.

Sentence,
Eighteen months' hard labour.

p.rs:
. Stealing the sum of £1 10s., the moneys of
James Campin, from his person.

div1.p: Mr. W. S. M. Knight prosecuted.

JAMES CAMPIN , 144, St. Mary's Road, Plaistow. On October 1 I received my Army Reserve pay. About ten o'clock in the morning of October 1 I came out of the Post Office, went across the road to the "Black Lien" public-house and stood outside, when prisoner came up. I had known him to speak to for about two or three years. I asked him to have a drink; we both went into the house and had two glasses of ale, for which I paid. I put 30s. in piece of paper in my waistcoat pocket—a sovereign and half a sovereign. Then we walked down to the "Green Gate," and had another drink. After that we went on a tram to the "Boleyn" tavern. We had one glass there, came out, and walked up Green Street. Prisoner asked me if I had my money all right I said, "Yes." I took it out of my waistcoat pocket, opened the paper, and showed it to him. He took it out of my band and put the 30s. in his pocket; then he put a halfpenny and a farthing into the paper and gave it to me. I took it, and said, "Thin won't do; I want my money." He said, "I have not got it." I asked him for it several times, and he said he had not got it. We got up to the "Queen's" public-house, and be said, "Come and have a drink." He went in, and I followed him. He had a glass of beer and offered me one. I refused. We then cams out, and I asked him for the money again. He would not give it to me, so I knocked him down and tried to get it that way; but his friends got round and got him away—three men named Hill, Stowe, and Ait. Prisoner went round some back turnings and I chased him, but lost him round by the Broadway, Plaistow. I gave information to the police, and the next time I saw prisoner was at Barking Road Police Station about a month after; he was amongst about ten other men and I picked him out.
Cross-examined. I was not drunk. I had two drinks in the first public-court and one in each of the others. I gave information to Detective-sergeant Stephens about it and gave him prisoner's name.

Detective Sergeant
STEPHENS , K Division, stationed at Plaistow. Prosecutor came to me some days after the offence took place. I made inquiries, and arrested prisoner on October 30.

Cross-examined. It was about nine days after the offence that prosecutor came to me, but there was a reason why he did not give informa
tion before.
(Defence).

ALBERT VINCENT (prisoner, on oath). I admit having drink with the prosecutor. we just went to the "Black Lion" and had five of six drinks there. We went to the "Green Gate" and had a tidy few, when prosecutor intermixed with four other men and two rough women. I said to him "Will you come home?" because I did not like the look of these people, they looked to me very bad, no I left his company at two o'clock in the afternoon. Prosecutor was drunk, and was remanded for attempting to commit suicide on the same day. I was only with him from ten o'clock till two.

Cross-examined. I never saw the paper or the coins. I did not go into the "Queen's Hotel" with him. I left him at the "Green Gate." He did not knock me down; he just pushed me because I said I did not like the look of the men and women. That was about a mile and a half away from the "Queen's" public-house. I had not been near the "Queen's" that day. Prosecutor said "What is it to do with you, I can spend my money where I like and treat who I like." After he pushed me down I walked away and left him with the four men and two women. He was trean
ing them I was not drunk. When I walked away prosecutor did not make any attempt to run after me. The first public we went to was the "Black Lion." He was treating anybody who came in. He went away from there with me. The next was the "Prince Albert," Broadway, plastron, that is about five minutes' walk from the "Black Lion." None of the other people went there with us. The next was the "Green Gate." He one lese went with us there. There he treated there of four men and two rough women. I had two or three drinks and I left him with these other people. The women got hold of him and danced with him. I knew he had some money but I only saw the money that he paid for the drinks. I only saw silver, no gold at all. I saw no money wrapped in paper. He pushed me down because I wanted him to go home and he wanted to stop with these women. I did not give him halfpenny and a farthing.

Detective-sergeant
STEPHENS , recalled. Prosecutor tried to consults suicide late that night by taking poision. He was alleged to have taken prussic acid, but the doctor said there were no signs of it. He was not taken up for being drunk. The story he told me was that he and prisoner were alone, and they got to the public-house the other people got round him.

JAMES CAMPIN , recalled. At the "Black Lion" I treated nobody but Vincent. We went from there straight to the "Green Gate" and had a glass each, came out and got on a tram. There were no other people at "Green Gate" that I know. We went from the "Green Gate" to the "Boleyn," and them up to the "Queen's Hotel. When I knocked him down the other men got round him. I had no beer in the "Queen's Hotel" at all. There were no women there.

Verdict,
Not Guilty.
